docs.snippet: The urban corps of Silver Angels, distinguished by their silvertoned Jeeps and silver-white uniforms, have received special training and instruction, and all speak at least one foreign language. For several years, Mexico City's ''Green Angels'' ha...
docs.lead_paragraph: The urban corps of Silver Angels, distinguished by their silvertoned Jeeps and silver-white uniforms, have received special training and instruction, and all speak at least one foreign language. For several years, Mexico City's ''Green Angels'' have patroled the highways in green trucks looking for motorists who need help changing a tire or replacing a broken fan belt. The two patrols' functions are complementary, according to an official of the Mexican National Tourist Council. The Green Angels are equipped to perform minor auto repairs and are trained to provide first-aid if required. The Silver Angels,''who provide protection and assistance,'' the tourist council said, deal with more serious problems like accidents, illness and lost property. He also conceded that the new squad might serve as a deterrent to thieves preying on tourists. A visitor who needs help from either of the patrols should telephone 588-51-00. Seagoing Spa On the QE2 With all those choices of steak and chicken, souffles and casseroles and rich desserts - not to mention between-meal treats and, of course, alcohol - cruise passengers often question whether it is possible to avoid putting on weight during a voyage.

headline.main: Travel Advisory; EXPLORERS, ANGELS AND GLADIATORS; Angel Aides to The Rescue in Mexico City; The ''Green Angels'' civilian Samaritans, who have been patrolling the highways in and around Mexico City for several years aiding motorists in distress have been joined by a new squad, the ''Silver Angels,'' composed of specially selected members of the Police Department

docs.lead_paragraph: AUCKLAND, New Zealand -- The Pacific offers the greatest scope for tourist development of any area in the world, in the opinion of delegates to the recent fourth annual conference of the Pacific Area Travel Association. Its potential is fabulous, they believe, and as yet it has hardly been touched. This is especially true for the South Pacific.

docs.snippet: SERGE SCHMEMANN is a correspondent for The New York Times in Moscow. By SERGE SCHMEMANN   If you find a great bargain in Russia, that is probably where it will stay. Not that tempting buys are hard to find. Tourists who slip away from their Intour...
docs.lead_paragraph: SERGE SCHMEMANN is a correspondent for The New York Times in Moscow. By SERGE SCHMEMANN If you find a great bargain in Russia, that is probably where it will stay. Not that tempting buys are hard to find. Tourists who slip away from their Intourist shepherds and into Moscow's commission shops - state used-goods stores that sell on commission - are likely to stumble on shiny, pre-revolutionary samovars with authentic markings for as little as $100.

docs.lead_paragraph: IF other vacationists are like our family, they have always been a little afraid of New York. It seemed like a nice place to visit, but how could one spend an entire vacation there and keep from going broke? The city, with its unlimited allures and demands, seemed unmanageable for a family vacation.

docs.snippet: FOREIGN visitors to Thailand with days to spare in the vicinity of Bangkok, and with a longing for a tropical island, can take a lesson from native Thais and head for Koh Samet, an eight-square-mile island in the Gulf of Thailand about four hours ...
docs.lead_paragraph: FOREIGN visitors to Thailand with days to spare in the vicinity of Bangkok, and with a longing for a tropical island, can take a lesson from native Thais and head for Koh Samet, an eight-square-mile island in the Gulf of Thailand about four hours southeast of the capital. Unlike Pattaya, the overbuilt mainland resort nearby, most of Koh Samet has been protected as a national park since 1981, with a ban on new building, and hotels and bungalows largely hidden behind trees. Shaped roughly like a miniature South America, Koh Samet has as its main attraction a series of bays, separated by rocky outcrops, that dot the length of the island's east side. Each has its own characteristics, but all have fine, squeaky white sand and azure waters. The island gets almost equal numbers of Thai and foreign visitors, and so it also provides a taste of how Thai people vacation sanuk-style -- ''sanuk'' being a Thai word that loosely means fun. On Koh Samet, it generally means crowds of families or students, appointed with hats, guitars, picnic baskets, whisky and all the flotsam of a stay at the beach. Many of them stay at family-style resorts at the most popular beach, Hat Sai Kaew, or camp out along the coast.
docs.abstract: Martha Stevenson Olson travel article on Koh Samet, Thailand; photos (L)
